title: The free things you CAN take from your hotel room (and ones you can't)
text:
15 shares 13
View
comments
There’s nothing thrifty holidaymakers love more than free stuff, especially when it comes to tiny bottles of shampoo or other complimentary items in a hotel room.
While the perks can range from stationary to event tickets, depending on the hotel’s star rating, some guests are willing to go a step further and nick bathrobes or pillows even though they risk being hit with a huge bill weeks later.
MailOnline Travel has compiled a list of free things guests can take from their rooms or request from the front desk, along with some amusing tales about those who were caught swiping items that were off-limits.
No matter how comfy that bathrobe is, you can't take it with you unless you're willing to pay a hefty charge
Toiletries
Miniature bottles of shampoo, conditioner and shower gel, and tiny bars of hand soap are the classic example of complimentary items in a hotel room.
They range from basic to high end, with five-star hotels offering luxurious lotions from designer brands such as Hermes or Bulgari.
Some guests will even sneakily raid the housekeeper’s trolley when no one is looking.
The tiny bottles are often at or below 100ml in size, meaning they’re perfect to take in hand luggage on the flight home.
Event tickets
Higher-end hotels are willing to go a little further to pamper their well-heeled guests, and they may throw in free tickets to events or tourist attractions.
In the Big Apple, the James New York hotel offers free tickets to the New Museum, Manhattan’s only dedicated contemporary art museum, through its Cultural Collection programme.
Other perks include free admission to outdoor screenings by the Lower East Side Film Festival, and educational programming hosted by The Drawing Center, a non-profit exhibition space.

Those who stay in four- and five-star hotels on a regular basis likely have a drawer at home filled with toothbrushes or single-use tubes of toothpaste.
Free toothbrushes are standard at Shangri-La hotels, for example, along with bath products from L’Occitane en Provence.
They’re rarely offered at budget or middle-of-the-road hotels, although guests can request them from the front desk if they forgot to pack theirs.
Other freebies can include razors, shaving cream, cotton ear buds, shoe shine cloths or sponges, sewing kits, combs and nail files.
Travelodge says some guests have tried to smuggle its king size Dreamer Beds out of its UK hotels
ITEMS TAKEN FROM HOTEL ROOMS Unopened toiletries (61,000 taken by guests) Light bulbs (53,000) Batteries (48,000) Towels (44,000) Plants (36,000) Bibles (34,000) Bath-mats (28,000) Duvet Covers (23,000) TV Remotes (17,000) Hairdryers (15,000) Source: Laterooms.com
Beds
It’s a no-brainer that a mattress or bed is not free and taking one would put a holidaymaker at risk of being charged with theft, but that hasn’t deterred some guests.
According to Travelodge, some guests have tried to smuggle its king size Dreamer Beds out of its hotels.
Shakila Ahmed, Travelodge spokeswoman, said: 'Since we have introduced our new brand design and modernised our hotel rooms across the country, we have seen a significant rise in our fluffy pillows, snuggly duvets, striped bed runners and contemporary artwork being taken from our 504 UK hotels.’
Food and drink
These days, it seems like almost every hotel room in the world – no matter the star rating – offers complimentary tea and coffee (plus sugar and artificial sweeteners) for guests.
In more expensive hotels, guests may find a Nespresso machine with a case stocked with capsules, or a bottle of Champagne to welcome them upon arrival.
But at most hotels, bottles of bubbly, spirits or beer are usually kept in the overpriced mini-bar.
Other freebies can include fruit, biscuits and packets of crisps to consume in the room or take home.
DoubleTree by Hilton gives out 77,000 free chocolate chip cookies to its guests each day, amounting to 28million a year.
Bob Atkinson, travel expert at TravelSupermarket, said: ‘One of the main areas guests get caught out when staying in a hotel is by being tempted by mini-bar snacks and drinks. That bottle of water so tempting to grab on our way out can come back to haunt us when we get lumped with an extortionate bill at the end of our stay.’
Slippers… and bathrobes?
Hotels with spas usually have at least two pairs of light-duty slippers in each room for guests to use in their rooms or take home with them. But they should double check before stuffing them in their suitcase.
Bathrobes are usually a no-no. Exclusive hotels may offer free ones, but that’s a rare scenario.
If guests check the information book or card in their room, they will notice in almost all cases that the robes are not free, but can be purchased from the front desk.
Mr Atkinson said: ‘Do not be tempted to snaffle dressing gowns, towels, ornaments, pictures on the wall, fixtures, TV remote controls, irons and hairdryers. ‘All of these are not “free” gifts however tempting they may be and you face having your card debited for these items. And that charge will not be cheap. If in any doubt at all then check with reception.’
Stationery
Notepads, panes, magazines and newspapers are all complimentary.
At the Trump Hotel Central Park in New York, guests request and receive personalized business cards and stationary at no cost.
When guests stay a second time they receive free luggage tags.
A study by Laterooms.com found that 34,000 Bibles are lifted from hotels by British travellers every year
Bibles and bathmats
A study by Laterooms.com found that 34,000 Bibles are lifted from hotels by British travellers every year, along with light bulbs, towels and TV remotes – thus breaking the eighth commandment.
Some light-fingered guests even took plants, bathmats and duvet covers, which are not complimentary.
Nearly half (45 per cent) of the 8,000 hotels who participated said the items most commonly taken are everyday objects like batteries and light bulbs.
In a separate study of nearly 1,330 British holidaymakers, more than two thirds admitted to stealing from hotels while on holiday abroad, said MyVoucherCodes.co.uk, which commissioned the survey.
Some of the most common items that people admitted to stealing were towels and linen, cutlery, picture frames, artwork, curtains and kettles.
Free gifts for kids (and pets)
Hotels are more than eager to welcome their youngest guests, showing children with all kinds of freebies to keep them and their parents happy.
At the Jefferson Hotel in Washington, DC, children can choose a free toy from a red wagon upon arrival.
Families who stay at Great Wolf Lodge, a chain of hotels and indoor water parks, can create a Shutterfly photo book for free with a promo code found in rooms.
The hotel also offers goodies for four-legged visitors, and will put dog bowls and beds inside the room before the guest arrives.
Ultimately, Mr Atkinson said, guests should make sure they know what is included in their nightly rate before they throw something in their luggage to take back home.
He said: ‘Items such as wifi, breakfast and parking are usually listed in the hotel details. If you’ve not planned ahead and budgeted for items that could be classed as extras, it can be a nasty surprise to realise you need to folk out on the day.’
